subNodes.conversationText: root
The mound of soil over the corpse looked rich and moist. The tomatoes were very red.
To begin the planting, <FirstName> would need the trowel Eldest Lady mentioned.
<FirstName> dug a hole in the soil.
<FirstName> didn't have the seed, though.
<He/She> would have to get it from the table.
<FirstName> placed the seed in the hole and covered it with loose soil.
Now <he/she> needed to water it. <He/She> would have to bring the pitcher of water from the table.
<FirstName> poured the water from the pitcher.
As <FirstName> watched the soil drink it down, <he/she> heard the witches chanting from the house:
[Continue.]

"More or less, less or more.
Death's a house without a door.
Life's a squatter, rank and poor.
More or less, less or more."
[Continue.]
A shoot emerged, then a vine, and then came leaves and buds and orange flowers. One flower was so big it rose up and obscured the sun.
[Continue.]
The flower wilted and fell like drapery over something upright on the grave. It was about as tall as <FirstName> but far bulkier. The witches were silent. <FirstName> felt their eyes on <him/her>.
<He/She> tore away the fallen flower.
Shreds fell. Beneath was an organic wall of mottled green with great yellow ridges.
[Continue.]

The object moved. The rest of the flower fell away. In its place stood an almost human figure dressed in a burlap jacket and carrying a staff. Its chest rose and fell, but it made no sound of breathing. How could it? It had no nose or mouth. It was a giant gourd.

The witches came out of the house.
[Continue.]
"This is our gift to you. His name is Knott. He'll protect you."
[Folk Magic] <FirstName> was amazed. <He/She>'d had no idea that magic of this sort was possible.
Eldest Lady saw <his/her> wonder. "I am called 'Eldest Lady' for a reason. I do more than give bad winds to sailors and backaches to farmers."
[Continue.]
"She also gives sweet milk to cats and stern commands to dogs."
[Continue.]
"Quiet, dog."
"You said its name is Knott?"
"Yes. His name."
"What is this creature?"
"I do not need such a servant."
"It grew from the dead witch's grave. Is it --?"
<FirstName> accepted the witch's gift.
"Knott? That's its name?"
"Yes. His name."
[Continue.]
"A male gourd -- but, alas, vegetable from head to foot."
[Continue.]
"He lacks the milk of human kindness."
[Continue.]
"And the milk of animal kindness," said Middle One in a pained voice.
"I do not need such a servant."
"It grew from the dead witch's grave. Is it --?"
<FirstName> accepted the witch's gift.
"What is this creature?"
"A gourd, more or less. One with legs and hands and a rough sort of intelligence."
[Continue.]
"A male gourd -- but, alas, vegetable from head to foot."
"I do not need such a servant."
The witches laughed. Middle One laughed like someone who'd suddenly learned they'd made a big fuss over nothing.
[Continue.]
"<He/She>'s right, of course! After all that, too. Who needs a walking gourd? Oh, sister, our brains are full of strange ideas. We've lived alone too long."
[Continue.]
"That's why <FirstName> needs Knott. We'd like <him/her> to live long enough to join us."
"What kind of creature is he?"
"A gourd, more or less. One with legs and hands and a rough sort of intelligence."
"It grew from the dead witch's grave. Is it --?"
"I suppose I have no choice."
Eldest Lady nodded. "Let him be your shield."
[Continue.]
"It grew from the dead witch's grave. Is it --?"
"No, no. She's dead and gone. But a witch in a grave is still a witch in a way, until the world reclaims her body completely. Knott couldn't have grown on a monk's grave."
[Continue.]
"A holy man's all hole and no seed."
[Continue.]
"Enough, Middle One."
"What kind of creature is he?"
"I do not need such a servant."
<FirstName> accepted the witch's gift.
<FirstName> accepted the witch's gift.
"Good, good. Let him be your shield."
[Continue.]
"His rind is thicker than yours."
[Continue.]

"The woods are dangerous. Not just hunters. The Congress of Moths is here, too."

Pharaoh croaked.
"The Congress of Moths? Here? Why?"
"Their malice is fickle. Their flights know no season."
[Continue.]
"More or less."
[Continue.]
"Quiet, Middle One." The reprimand was sharp.
[Continue.]
"I only meant to say," said Middle One, "that they might have come to plague the woods because of our sister's murder."
[Continue.]

Eldest Lady appeared to consider this.

"Perhaps... But it's useless making guesses about them. Be a good example for and talk less."
"So the Congress of Moths is real? I didn't believe the stories."
"A pox on the ignorance of today's witches. Yes, yes. Real and dangerous."
"I'm ready. I'll be careful."
"Good. What's today's date, Middle One?"
"The Congress of Moths is real?"
"A pox on the ignorance of today's witches. Yes, yes. Real and dangerous."
[Continue.]
"Jolly in murder, hateful in mirth."
[Continue.]
"Reveling in mystery, doling out affliction to any who cross their paths."
"Why are they here?"
"They would sooner kill you than explain themselves."
[Continue.]
"Their malice is fickle. Their flights know no season."
"I'm ready. I'll be careful."
"We'll be careful."
"Good. What's today's date, Middle One?"
[Continue.]
"August 5th. Morning. The breeze is in the southeast, and I anticipate fine weather for the next week."
[Continue.]
"Return to us with the hunter's blood on the eleventh of August. Do not dawdle."
"What happens if I take longer?"

"Then you fail. Our sabbath begins at noon on that day, and the blood must bind you to us then or never. If you fail, we'll have to wait another year to complete the coven with someone else. And we're old, . The coven sustains us. Without it, we can't know that we'll last that long."
"Then I'll not fail."
"Come back around seven. You'll eat and sleep here. Be punctual; we are old and accustomed to our habits."
"Very well."
"Very well."
"Come back around seven. You'll eat and sleep here. Be punctual; we are old and accustomed to our habits."
[Continue.]

The three witches went into the house. Knott followed close behind. The two older witches said farewell to <FirstName>, and soon <he/she> was standing outside. The grim walking gourd stood beside <him/her>. Pharaoh eyed the forest.
This wasn't at all what <FirstName> had expected.
<He/She> thought back.
<He/She> had imagined soft-spoken mentors who'd keep a teapot going and pass on wisdom in mild tones.
Eldest Lady and Middle One had not offered tea to <FirstName>.
[Continue.]

Instead, 'd been roughly welcomed, ordered to procure the blood of a murderer, and cast into peril.

looked at the August sun and how it lit the meadows through which 'd come. looked at the woods and the night still lingering there. Then set off.
[End.]

actions.a_parameter_1:
NEW JOURNAL ENTRY
The Three Hunters: Bloodbound

Eldest Lady and Middle One sent the young witch and Knott on a grim errand -- to find the hunter who used goose-fletched arrows and to return with a pint of that hunter's blood before noon on August 11. They would use the blood to bind the young witch to their coven.

subNodes.conversationText: <He/She> had imagined the coven would be more -- perfunctory, a light obligation to endure as <he/she> learned.
<He/She> had even hoped the witches might recognize <his/her> talent and treat <him/her> as an equal.
[Continue.]

Instead, 'd been roughly welcomed, ordered to procure the blood of a murderer, and cast into peril.

looked at the August sun and how it lit the meadows through which 'd come. looked at the woods and the night still lingering there. Then set off.
<He/She> had imagined a collective of four or five covens full of beautiful young people.
There would be songs under starlight, midsummer revels, little jealousies and passions. <He/She> would be sung to, asked to dance, kissed.
[Continue.]

Instead, 'd been roughly welcomed, ordered to procure the blood of a murderer, and cast into peril.

looked at the August sun and how it lit the meadows through which 'd come. looked at the woods and the night still lingering there. Then set off.
<FirstName> had tried not to form expectations about Eldest Lady and Middle One.
After all, more often than not witches were supposed to upset them.
But it was hard not to recall <his/her> daydreams.
<He/She> thought back.
<He/She> had imagined soft-spoken mentors who'd keep a teapot going and pass on wisdom in mild tones.
<He/She> had imagined the coven would be more -- perfunctory, a light obligation to endure as <he/she> learned.
<He/She> had imagined a collective of four or five covens full of beautiful young people.
<He/She> was ready to begin.
<He/She> looked at the August sun and how it lit the meadows through which <he/she> had come. <He/She> looked at the woods and the night still lingering there. Then <he/she> set off.
[End.]

The drapery shriveled. Beneath, <FirstName> could see mottled green and yellow.
[Continue.]

<FirstName> brought out the witches' seed.
<FirstName> placed the seed in the hole and covered it with loose soil.

<FirstName> poured the water from the pitcher.
As <FirstName> watched the soil drink it down, <he/she> heard the witches chanting from the house:
<FirstName> left the grave alone.
<FirstName> returned to the grave.
To begin the planting, <FirstName> would need the trowel Eldest Lady mentioned.
<FirstName> dug a hole in the soil.
